intro: Absinthium frigidum var. gmelinianum, commonly known as the Arctic wormwood, is a perennial herb native to the Arctic and subarctic regions. It is characterized by its finely divided, silver-gray leaves and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant thrives in nutrient-poor, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold climates. It is often found growing in tundra and alpine environments. Due to its hardy nature, it plays a role in stabilizing soil in harsh, polar ecosystems.

Its distribution is limited to the northernmost parts of the Northern Hemisphere where the climate remains cool and frost persists for much of the year.
